conclusion: Determine the potential difference between points a and b when the circular ring is in the position where ∠aOb = 90°.
The circular ring is moving in a magnetic field, and the induced emf can be calculated using Faraday's law of induction.
The emf induced in the ring is given by the rate of change of the magnetic flux through the ring.
The magnetic flux Φ through the ring is given by Φ = B ⋅ A where A is the area of the ring.
For a circular ring of radius R, the area A is A = π R².
Therefore, the magnetic flux is Φ = B ⋅ π R².
The rate of change of the magnetic flux is dΦ/dt = B ⋅ π R² ⋅ d/dt(0) = 0 because the area of the ring is constant.
The emf is due to the motion of the wire segments in the magnetic field.
When ∠aOb = 90°, the wire segments ab and ob are involved in the emf calculation.
The length of the wire segment ab can be found using the geometry of the circle.
The angle ∠aOb = 90° means that the segment ab is part of the quarter-circle.
The length of the wire segment ab is L_ab = R θ where θ is the angle in radians.
Since ∠aOb = 90° = π/2 radians, the length of ab is L_ab = R ⋅ π/4.
The length of the wire segment ob is the radius R.
The induced emf in the wire segment ab is EMF_ab = B ⋅ v ⋅ L_ab = B ⋅ v ⋅ R ⋅ π/4 = π B v R/4.
The induced emf in the wire segment ob is EMF_ob = B ⋅ v ⋅ L_ob = B ⋅ v ⋅ R = B v R.
The potential difference between points a and b is the difference in the emfs of the segments ab and ob.
V_ab = EMF_ob - EMF_ab = B v R - π B v R/4 = B v R (1 - π/4).
The potential difference between points a and b is B v R (1 - π/4).
